Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Customer Discovery for a Semi-Powered Transtibial Prosthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is a novel prosthesis that addresses many health concerns addressed by the more than 600,000 individuals in the lower limb amputee population. The amputee population exhibits many day-to-day challenges associated with mobility tasks such as descending stairs, or even level ground walking. This projects seeks to develop an ankle prosthesis that addresses many of these needs while maintaining a small, quiet, and lightweight package. No other prosthesis on the commercial market exhibits the same functionality as this device, and therefore, there exists a gap in the market that can be filled by this device.

This I-Corps project is based on a novel ankle prosthesis, utilizing a novel actuator. This novel actuator allows this device to exhibit the following three mechanical functions: 1) high torque locking under load; 2) high-power dissipation under load; and 3) low-power generation in the absence of a load. These functions allow amputees to adapt to various terrains, gain support during standing, perform stair descent like healthy subjects as well as lift their toe during swing to avoid tripping. A prototype device has been created, and is to be assessed on amputees to determine its biomechanical benefit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Intellectual Merit of this proposal includes the discovery of pain points and problems faced by amputees, insurers, and prosthetists with commercially available ankle prostheses. The proposal will also help the investigators assess the commercial potential of a novel ankle prosthesis as previously described. The proposal will also allow the investigators to begin drafting a business model that will allow the adoption and distribution of this new prosthetic ankle. Broader Impacts will be achieved by introducing a new class of ankle prosthetic devices that incorporate a large degree of functionality in a small device. While many different research groups are pursuing large, heavy, and powerful robotic prosthetic devices, this work helps elucidate the benefit of leveraging passive dynamics and minimal power to provide biomechanical benefit to the amputee population. Additionally, much of the device?s design revolves around providing health benefits to amputees such as reducing the risk of falls and reducing contralateral limb loading (linked to the development of osteoarthritis). Such health benefits may greatly reduce the financial burden of an amputation on the amputee population, in addition to providing a general increase in quality of life.

 

Outcomes of the program include the conduct of over 100 customer interviews associated with the proposed prosthesis design, and the construction of a business plan to guide the development of a viable business startup. A startup company (Synchro Motion LLC) was subsequently formed, and based on the lessons learned from the program, the research team (Bartlett, Lawson, and Goldfarb) authored an NSF Phase I proposal, which was subsequently funded and currently supports research at Synchro Motion. The investigators also won first place in a pitch competition, which included a $20k prize to support the business venture. The investigators have subsequently licensed intellectual property from Vanderbilt University; are currently pursuing the development plan constructed during the ICORR program; plan to write a Phase II proposal pending the successful achievement of Phase I gating criteria; and plan to bring the innovation to market in conjunction with the completion of the Phase II work.
